section.name: Concepts
section.span: The concepts of the site toolkit explained.
section.p: The Site Toolkit is a set of components that allows web developers to create web sites within a Hippo ECM environment. It is based on the concept of modules: reusable chunks of functionality from which web pages and indeed complete web sites can be assembled. This assembly is made possible by two additional concepts: layouts and sitemap. Basically, the sitemap defines for each URL in a web site, which layout is used, and which modules.

subsection.name: Modules
subsection.p: Modules are chunks of well defined functionality, that can be displayed as part of a web page. A web page can be made up of many modules, each implementing a different functionality. Modules can be (re)used on different web pages.
Examples of modules are a list of news articles, a search form, a list of related articles, and a navigational menu.
Modules are implemented as a Java class, and have a view written in JSP.

subsection.name: Layouts
subsection.p: Layouts describe how modules are laid out on a page. Layouts are abstract wireframes: they only describe placeholders for modules, they don't actually define which particular modules are used. This makes layouts reusable on different pages.
As an example, consider a 3-column page layout such as visualized in the drawing below:

The layout identifies 4 placeholders or "containers": Header, LeftNav, Content, and RightNav. On one page, Content could contain a module displaying a news article, and RightNav a module displaying related news articles. Yet on a different page, Content could contain a module displaying a list of news articles published on a certain date, and RightNav a calendar module to let the user select a date.
Layouts consist of a configuration stored in the repository, and a JSP defining the contours of the web page, and the exact locations of the containers in the page.

subsection.name: Sitemap
subsection.p: The sitemap is the main controller in the site toolkit. The sitemap defines the URL space of a web site, attaches a layout to each page, and modules the a layout's containers.
As an example, consider the figure below:

In the top left corner is the 3-column layout. In the bottom left corner is a bunch of modules. Right in the middle of the figure is the sitemap, which assigns the 3-column layout to the URL "/home", and assigns a module to each container in the layout. The result is a complete web page that is displayed when the URL "/home" is requested.
The sitemap consists of a configuration stored in the repository. This configuration is managed through a GUI.
